To women and LGBTQ folks across this country: know that I’m mad as hell and fighting with everything I have to stand up to this draconian, extremist attack on your rights.
The freedom of millions of Americans is at risk. We must use EVERY tool we have to protect reproductive freedom, including abolishing the filibuster to pass this legislation.

I ran and won against one of the last anti-abortion and anti-LBGTQ+ Democrats in Congress. And it is exactly why I’m not going to let a group of unelected old white men tell me or my daughter what we can or cannot do with our own bodies or with the people we love.

I am terrified that not just Roe, but other crucial rights now appear to be up for debate.
 
As the mother of a transgender woman, I am deeply worried that her rights will be struck down next. This decision is dangerous for marginalized communities across the country.

I know first-hand that the freedom to decide when and under what circumstances to raise a family is crucial to gender equality and the principle that government can and should not interfere with personal medical decisions.

I’m grateful for the decision I made more than 30 years ago. I’m even more grateful to have had the freedom to make that decision.
 
I had a life ahead of me that would eventually put me in a place where I would one day be ready to start a family.

When I found out I was pregnant, I was only 19 years old and barely halfway through college. There was no way I could afford to have a baby.
 
A few days after my positive pregnancy test, I visited a local reproductive care clinic to have an abortion.

I never intended to share the story of my abortion publicly.
 
But with the Supreme Court set to upend a half-century guaranteed right to an abortion in the United States, I felt it was necessary.

The adoption of fire sprinklers in the last 40 years has led to an almost 50% reduction in fire deaths in the US.

Yet, we continue to see far too many firefighter and resident deaths that are caused by fires spreading in older high-rise buildings due to a lack of sprinklers.

The current tax code treats fire sprinklers the same as plumbing and their costs are depreciated over 39 years.

Our High-Rise Fire Sprinkler Incentive Act simply decreases this cost recovery to 15 years, incentivizing building owners to install fire sprinklers.

🚨BIG NEWS: I joined @BillPascrell & @RepJohnKatko today in introducing bipartisan legislation to protect our firefighters.

This bill amends the tax code to create a new incentive for owners to install sprinklers in residential buildings that were erected before fire codes.🧵👇

Under this bill, veterans who served in or near the Panama Canal Zone would be granted presumptive herbicide exposure status.

That means they could finally receive federal benefits and disability compensation from the U.S. Department of Veteran Affairs.

I'm proud to say we've made progress on this bill.

In the defense budget that the House passed this fall, we were able to secure an amendment that would direct the @DeptofDefense to conduct a study on the herbicide agent exposure in the Panama Canal Zone.
https://t.co/k44oaIhmxP

Now, he lives without the use of a pancreas after developing diabetes and growing 14 stones inside his pancreas.

He filed a claim with the VA for help after locating PROOF of U.S. exports of herbicides to PCZ.

Twice, the VA has denied his claim for disability compensation. https://t.co/Hu1l2TfM1A
Even though VA coverage is offered for those who served in Vietnam, the Korean DMZ and on the base in Thailand — PCZ veterans do not qualify and have never been given the opportunity to be heard.

We have a fundamental obligation to honor our veterans by providing them with the care they deserve.

That's why I introduced the bipartisan Panama Canal Zone Veterans Act w/ @RepMariaSalazar.

Gene is an Army veteran who served in the Panama Canal Zone (PCZ) from 1974 to 1977. He remembers how something was sprayed to defoliate the jungle nearly every day.

After his service ended, Gene's health deteriorated. And for over 20 years, he was in and out of the hospital. https://t.co/4QW5B9a2aG
